title: The Differences Between Lactose Intolerance and Milk Allergy

content: I'm a registered dietitian, and plenty of people have told me that they’re allergic to milk when they really have lactose intolerance. It’s important to distinguish between the two conditions, as one results in passing symptoms while the other is potentially life-threatening. Here’s the difference between lactose intolerance and a milk allergy, and why using the correct terminology matters.

Lactose is a carbohydrate found naturally in milk and milk products such as ice cream. Under normal conditions, the body breaks down and absorbs lactose in the small intestine. People who don’t make enough lactase, the enzyme that digests lactose, experience lactose malabsorption. That’s when lactose passes to the colon (large intestine) and is fermented by gut bacteria, resulting in symptoms such as bloating, gas, pain, nausea, or diarrhea, within minutes to a few hours of eating.

Lactose intolerance typically starts developing after the age of 1. It’s relatively common in the U.S., affecting 36% of the population.  Lactose intolerance tends to be genetic. You’re more likely to have it if your family or you are from an area where it’s more prevalent. African Americans, Native Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanics/Latinos have a greater rate of lactose intolerance.

content: Infection and conditions that cause injury to the small intestine, including celiac disease, Crohn's disease, and radiation therapy, can lead to lactose intolerance, which may be temporary. While some premature babies are lactose intolerant, the condition usually improves without treatment as the baby matures.

Lactose intolerance can be annoying and unpleasant, but it’s good to know that it’s not serious. Although the symptoms of lactose intolerance pass, the condition can have lasting effects on your health when you don’t replace the nutrients in dairy foods with other foods or dietary supplements. This includes protein, calcium, and vitamin D.

To diagnose lactose intolerance, doctors typically ask about your symptoms, family and medical history, and eating habits. They may order a hydrogen breath test to see how well your small intestine digests lactose . You may also be asked to stop eating and drinking milk and milk products for a few days to a week to see if your symptoms disappear.

sections.heading: Managing Lactose Intolerance
content: Lactose intolerance is personal. Some people can tolerate foods with very little lactose, including yogurt and cheddar or Swiss cheese, while others can’t. Some people have fewer symptoms when they consume lactose with other foods, such as pairing a glass of milk with a sandwich.

You may also be able to use lactase products, which are tablets or drops that contain lactase. Take lactase products before you eat or drink dairy foods or other foods with lactose. Lactose may be added to packaged foods including processed meats, baked goods, and salad dressings, so read ingredient labels. Lactose-free and reduced-lactose milk, cottage cheese, and ice cream are also available at grocery stores and have the same nutritional content as their regular counterparts.

A milk allergy is a disorder of the immune system. With a milk allergy, your body’s immune system overreacts to the protein in milk, which it interprets as a threat. Milk is one of the most common food allergens. If you’re allergic to cow’s milk, you may also be allergic to milk from sheep, goats, and other animals.

content: Infants can develop a milk allergy within the first year of life. Milk allergies are most often diagnosed with a skin-prick test or a blood test. About 80% of children with a milk allergy outgrow it before age 16.

Symptoms of a milk allergy can range from mild to life-threatening. The signs of a milk allergy include hives, an upset stomach, vomiting, bloody stools, and anaphylaxis, which can lead to anaphylactic shock. Anaphylaxis affects your ability to breathe and causes a sudden drop in blood pressure, dizziness, and fainting. People with a milk allergy should always carry an auto-injector that contains epinephrine, as that’s the only way to treat anaphylactic shock.

People with a milk allergy must avoid milk or items containing milk products. Under U.S. law, manufacturers of packaged food products sold in this country must label their products as having milk or milk products on the ingredient label. Milk proteins may be found in unexpected foods such as canned tuna, deli meats, and even in chewing gum, so read labels carefully.
